title: How to find books I want for free - Quora

response.answer_text: Libraries are great places to read free books. If you live in most any civilized country, they’ll have one, though I think America has many more. It’s easy to get a library card. Bookbub and Goodreads are good places to seek out free books. They do have free books available, though most are merely reduced in price. On the other hand, .99 or $1.99 is not a bad price. I have never taken a free book because I’ve never seen an offering with which I was familiar, either title or author; if I ever see one that I know of in advance—snatch! Goodreads has book giveaways, though many people enter and few win. If you go on the Internet, just type in “free books,” and you’ll get a list of places to check out. Inexpensive books are available at used book stores, library book sales, and thrift stores. I enjoy “the hunt,” and part of the fun is coming across a title I don’t own and haven’t seen in an eternity, then getting it at a bargain price. I once got a hardback copy of *Nicholas and Alexandra* by Robert K. Massie, a classic biography / history for $5, and when I took it home, I found it was *autographed!* Even if I return home with nothing (a rare event), I’ve had fun looking. Ask a book-owner to borrow books he / she owns. I really enjoy it when someone asks to borrow one of my books, though I do have a price: when you return it, tell me if you liked it (or didn’t) and why. I enjoy such discussions. Happy hunting!

You local library has a large collection of books that you can read for free, and often they have ebooks you can borrow as well. You can usually request books there if they don’t have them, too. You may also be able to join groups or fan clubs for the types of books you want, and take advantage of author giveaways and free book promotions. Often authors will give away the first book in a series for free, in order to inspire people to buy the rest. (After all, if people don’t BUY books, authors have no reason to write them in the first place; we aren’t doing this as charity work)! :) There are many reasons a person would be unable to afford to buy books; and that’s why public libraries exist. Libraries buy the books that are in their collection, so authors don’t lose out completely. Hope this helps. :)

Thank you for the A2A. My best bet would be for you to join a book club of sorts. I am a chronic book hoarder myself and I have my own book club where a bunch of us friends exchange whatever books we have with each other. And these are eBooks. Most of the books I have have been emailed to me by friends who have Kindle subscriptions. Some of them, I’ve bought from places like Amazon and some others I found them online by sheer accident.

Try your public library. There are absolute eons of books on the shelves, and I truly live walking in there. The only time you have to pay is if you get fined for an overdue or damaged book.  I've had a library card since I was about 5. The past couple of years, I haven't used it much due to not having enough time on my hands to justify checking out at least four new books. I love it. The librarians are helpful, and lovely, and you get free books!

The library! Also Google: “free books online” Amazon has used books for incredibly low prices. So do used book stores and some thrift stores. Google: “used bookstores” or “second hand bookstores” or “thrift stores.” Or look them up in the phone book.
